links.title: Threaded code - Wikipedia
links.description: In computer science, the term threaded code refers to a programming technique where the code has a form that essentially consists entirely of calls to subroutines. It is often, but not only, found in compiler implementations that generate code in that form and/or are implemented in that form themselves. The code may be processed by an interpreter, or may simply be a sequence of machine code call instructions.

links.title: Ragel State Machine Compiler
links.description:
Ragel compiles executable finite state machines from regular languages.
Ragel targets C, C++ and ASM. Ragel state
machines can not only recognize byte sequences as regular expression machines
do, but can also execute code at arbitrary points in the recognition
of a regular language. Code embedding is done using inline operators that do
not disrupt the regular language syntax.

Introduction

Structuring a large program is always a difficult job. One of the
particular problems that often comes up is this: if you have a piece
of code producing data, and another piece of code consuming it,
which should be the caller and which should be the callee?

equally simple piece of parser code:

links.title: Employment in families with children in 2016 : The Economics Daily : U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics
links.description: In 2016, 34.2 million families included children under age 18, about two-fifths of all families. Among married-couple families with children, 96.8 percent had at least one employed parent, and 61.1 percent had both parents employed. Married-couple families whose youngest child was 6 to 17 years old were more likely to have both parents employed (64.7 percent) than families in which the youngest child was under 6 years old (56.3 percent).

Programmed Instruction, Learning, or Teaching (PILOT) is a simple programming language developed in the 1960s.[1]
Like its younger sibling LOGO, it was an early foray into the technology of computer-assisted instruction.

links.title: Logo (programming language) - Wikipedia
links.description: Logo is an educational programming language, designed in 1967 by Wally Feurzeig, Seymour Papert, and Cynthia Solomon.[1] Logo is not an acronym: the name was coined by Feurzeig while he was at Bolt, Beranek and Newman,[2] and derives from the Greek logos, meaning word or thought.

links.title: Radio fingerprinting - Wikipedia
links.description: Radio fingerprinting is a process that identifies a cellular phone or any other radio transmitter by the "fingerprint" that characterizes its signal transmission and is hard to imitate. An electronic fingerprint makes it possible to identify a wireless device by its radio transmission characteristics. Radio fingerprinting is commonly used by cellular operators to prevent cloning of cell phones ‚Äî a cloned device will have a same numeric equipment ...

links.title: Amateur radio direction finding - Wikipedia
links.description: Amateur radio direction finding (ARDF, also known as radio orienteering and radiosport) is an amateur racing sport that combines radio direction finding with the map and compass skills of orienteering. It is a timed race in which individual competitors use a topographic map, a magnetic compass and radio direction finding apparatus to navigate through diverse wooded terrain while searching for radio transmitters. The rules of the sport and interna...
